My wife's cat absconded for about 3 months and came back, still in good physical condition, and behaved as though she'd never been away. Later, we found out that she had been living about 2 miles away at a house where the food was presumably superior.

I am a dog person myself. Cats I just tolerate, or as George said, they tolerate me . 
 
 The short hair jumps up on the end table beside my TV recliner , and turns its tail end towards me, just as I take the first bite out of my sandwich . The long hair cats hair ,adequately covers their rear end to obstruct the view of the offending exit mechanism. The short hair cat needs a toupee over the offending hole, because it is not very appetizing to see, while I am eating my sandwich. Do pets store not carry cat butt toupees ? If not, there is a market for them , that someone needs to fill for these short hair cats . I cannot be the only one out here with this problem, :):)

My problem is not with cats, it's with cat owners. My community has leash laws if you own a dog, however, many cat owners feel it's acceptable to open the front door and let their cats roam freely to prey on anything to small or slow to escape them. This especially aggravates me when I see it happening on someone else's property other than the cat owner's: (like mine). I spent a considerable amount of money installing a fence to ensure my dogs stayed on my property and didn't bother my neighbors, if only my neighbors would reciprocate.

 Well, if you believe that cats shouldn't be let out at all, that's one thing. There's some validity in your argument, certainly. But I do think the majority of cat owners already agree with you - letting our cats out is generally a bad idea, but mostly for the cat's sake. It presents more opportunities to catch diseases and get killed in the road. But I think the problem you mention, that of small birdies and such getting killed, has more to do with the larger feral cat population than just domestic cats let loose. I wouldn't mind if my cat brought back the occasional kill (though I would feel bad for the bird) - that's what cats do, they hunt. But this only becomes a problem when you look at the large number of uncontrolled feral cats than can wreak havok on a bird population. And controlling those is another issue entirely.
 
 I think it's great you have a fence to keep your dogs in. But let's face it, what possible good would a fence do with cats? Either we work on legislation to keep all pet cats indoors at all times, or we just deal with the fact that they're mature enough to handle themselves outdoors, whereas dogs aren't. :)
 
 
You certainly make a good point. I have found that most cat lovers are liberals. Liberalism is a form of mental illness. That explains alot about cat lovers.

Even if you're just being facetious, your comment is completely out of line here. This is a discussion board, and in not one of your posts have you ever discussed anything - you just make ignorant, sometimes slanderous assertions and then run away when someone presents a logical rebuttal. A mind is a terrible thing to waste. I hope you'll make better use of yours in the future.

Well, if you believe that cats shouldn't be let out at all, that's one thing. There's some validity in your argument, certainly. But I think the problem you mention, that of small birdies and such getting killed, has more to do with the larger feral cat population than just domestic cats let loose.  I understand your point about feral cats, but I'm referring to domestic pets that live within walking distance of my home. I have bird feeders set up on my property and don't appreciate my neighbor's cats stalking the very birds I attract with my feeders. I don't care whether or not owners let their cats out as long as they don't become a nuisance to me. If they can't account for their whereabouts, they shouldn't let them out. Where do you think all the feral cats originated from? My guess is they're the end result of unsupervised cats that go astray and breed in the wild; again reinforcing my point. The domestic "cat" wasn't an animal that roamed in the wild before humans introduced them into the environment. You could make the same argument for the wild dogs that run in packs because they've bred with other stray dogs.
 
 
I think it's great you have a fence to keep your dogs in. But let's face it, what possible good would a fence do with cats? Either we work on legislation to keep all pet cats indoors at all times, or we just deal with the fact that they're mature enough to handle themselves outdoors, whereas dogs aren't. :)
 .

 
 That's your rebuttal to cats trespassing on other's property? By your logic you shouldn't have any problems with people keeping any species as pet and letting them do what comes natural to them as long as they don't threaten humans directly. I would agree that the cats possess a certain level of maturity: maybe someday their owner's will catch up.

I've got a cousin that's an ornithologist, he DESPISES domestic cats, or maybe more correctly, CAT OWNERS.
 
 According to him, and I don't have any hard evidence but I'm sure he could supply it if anyone so desired, domestic cats are the single largest predator on song birds in North America, accouting for the majority of the mortality rate in many species.
 
 DO NOT LET YOUR CAT "RUN FREE".
 
 As for me, I've got ZERO use for cats, well, maybe one. ;)

 I'm simply not that passionate about this issue to debate it until the end - and the fact is, you're right about many things. There's basically two types of irresponsibility we're talking about here. The first being cats being let out in the first place. As I said, its dangerous for the cats. However, many people simply feel that this is where their cats belong, where they're happiest. This leads to the second issue, which is spaying/neutering those outdoor cats. Now, if all pet owners who aren't breeding cats have them spayed or neutered, as they should, then this would go a long way towards cutting down on the feral population, which would ease the burden on the bird population. 
 
 
That's your rebuttal to cats trespassing on other's property? By your logic you shouldn't have any problems with people keeping any species as pet and letting them do what comes natural to them as long as they don't threaten humans directly. I would agree that the cats possess a certain level of maturity: maybe someday their owner's will catch up.

All I said was if my cat takes out the occasional bird (not someone's pet, mind you), that I would not consider it punishable behavior, nor would I be particularly proud of it. If it were terrorizing a bird-feeder crowd, I would make an effort to find a solution since I don't want to incur the wrath of my neighbor, especially if it's jskufan. And if it ransacked your house as you describe, then I would pay you for damages and keep my cat indoors, though only after having a good private chuckle over it since anyone who could suggest cruelty to animals like that deserves to have their place peed in. Incidentally, if my cat should die after being shot by you, then don't be upset when the police pick you up for animal cruelty. It's just one of those things cops do.

 Fishpower, that's one of the disadvantages of the written word, sometimes you don't get a good read on someone's intent. Somehow this thread has gotten sidetracked and has turned into a debate between you and I on the behavior of cat owners. Like yourself, I am an animal lover, thus explaining why I go to the trouble to feed all the little critters that visit my bird feeders. That's why I get bent out of shape when I see my neighbor's cats stalking the birds as they feed in my yard. It's not like they need to hunt for food, they usually just hunt for sport. Also like yourself, I'm non-confrontational. In the 20 years I've lived next to these people, I've never complained once to them. I vented here because the topic was pertinent. They could purchase a collar with bells for the cat, at least that would offer some warning that it's in the vicinity. Like most every other thing that bothers me in my neighborhood, I'll turn the other cheek and look the other way. I don't think these people are purposefully trying to upset me, I just think they're clueless. You can bet if my dogs were running around "visiting" everyone's house like the cats are, there would be plenty of grumblings in the neighborhood. Anyway, I've said my peace.
